title: SB 972
content: The State of California enacts the following. The Second Validating Act of 2016, also known as the Second Validating Act, defines "public body" as state departments, agencies, boards, commissions, cities, counties, districts, and other entities. This includes various agencies and districts such as air pollution control districts, airport districts, and assessment districts. Various districts and authorities in California including bridge and highway districts, water districts, pest control districts, city maintenance districts, community college districts, community development commissions, community facilities districts, conservancy districts, county boards of education, county drainage districts, county flood control and water districts, county library systems, county sanitation districts, county transportation commissions, and county water agencies. County water authorities, districts, and waterworks districts, along with various other agencies and districts such as fire protection districts, garbage disposal districts, harbor districts, health care authorities, highway districts, housing authorities, and irrigation districts. Various types of districts and authorities exist, including integrated financing districts, irrigation districts, joint highway districts, library districts, local health care districts, maintenance districts, and nonprofit corporations. Other entities include mosquito abatement districts, municipal utility districts, parking authorities, port districts, and public cemetery districts. Various types of districts and authorities exist, such as property improvement areas, protection districts, public utility districts, rapid transit districts, reclamation districts, and recreation and park districts. Other entities include regional justice facility financing agencies, resort improvement districts, resource conservation districts, and school districts of any kind. Additionally, there are sewer districts, small craft harbor districts, storm drain maintenance districts, toll tunnel authorities, and transit development boards. The curr_chunk lists various types of districts and authorities, including storm water districts, toll tunnel authorities, transit development boards, water agencies, and public libraries. It also specifies exclusions such as community redevelopment agencies and community development commissions. The curr_chunk defines "public body" to include specific agencies like the successor agency to the Redevelopment Agency of the City and County of San Francisco for issuing bonds. The curr_chunk defines various terms related to bonds, including "Bonds," "Hereafter," "Heretofore," and "Now." SEC. 3 declares all public bodies previously organized under any law to be legally functioning. SEC. 4 confirms the boundaries of public bodies as previously established. SEC. 5 validates the legality of public body boundaries shown on maps or plats used by the assessor. SEC. 5 confirms and validates all past actions taken by public bodies regarding annexation, inclusion, detachment, consolidation, merger, or dissolution of territories. SEC. 6 authorizes, confirms, and validates all past actions related to the issuance of bonds by public bodies for public purposes. All bonds issued by public bodies for public purposes are legally binding obligations, whether issued in the past, sold to a purchaser, authorized by ordinance or resolution, or approved at an election. Bonds authorized by a public body through an election and issued in accordance with that authorization are legally binding obligations. SEC. 7 of this act validates past acts and proceedings within constitutional limits, excluding those currently under legal dispute. SEC. 8 states that this act does not legalize any act previously deemed illegal or void, nor does it authorize contracts between public bodies and the United States. Any challenge to the validity of actions taken under laws related to the formation, organization, or boundaries of public bodies must be filed within six months of this act's effective date. Otherwise, such actions will be considered valid and legally binding. This act does not extend the time limit for legal action beyond what is already allowed by existing statutes. The curr_chunk states that it allows for legal action beyond the existing statute of limitations. The act allows for legal action beyond the existing statute of limitations and specifies the requirements for the creation or changes in public bodies for assessment or taxation purposes. It will become effective on September 1, 2016, and is deemed an urgency statute for the immediate preservation of public peace, health, or safety.
